pullRequest.body:
We define `Sequence α` as the type of sequences with length 0, 1, or `ω`, and give a basic API. A subsequent PR will introduce the notion of a (countable and computable) fundamental sequence and establish basic results.

The goal of this is to generalize [`ONote.fundamentalSequence`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/Notation.html#ONote.fundamentalSequence) to allow the construction of fundamental sequences for other ordinal notations.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

See [my ordinal notation repository](https://github.com/vihdzp/ordinal-notation/blob/a6fdd7fe7cb521e686ea271902e7e5496f1804d3/OrdinalNotation/Cantor.lean#L1218) for a demonstration of how this API looks in practice.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [cc63e7bda5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18463/commits/cc63e7bda545335f67e04cdf5398355dc7f3b94d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Notation`|-740|
| `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Notation.FundamentalSequence` (new file)|106|
| `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Notation.Cantor`|740|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Sequence`
`+ attach`
`+ attach_empty`
`+ attach_eq_empty_iff`
`+ attach_ofFun`
`+ attach_singleton`
`+ empty_def`
`+ empty_ne_ofFun`
`+ empty_ne_singleton`
`+ instance : EmptyCollection (Sequence α) := ⟨empty⟩`
`+ instance : Inhabited (Sequence α) := ⟨∅⟩`
`+ instance : Membership α (Sequence α)`
`+ instance : Singleton α (Sequence α) := ⟨singleton⟩`
`+ map`
`+ map_empty`
`+ map_eq_empty_iff`
`+ map_ofFun`
`+ map_singleton`
`+ mem_attach`
`+ mem_map`
`+ mem_ofFun`
`+ mem_ofFun_iff`
`+ mem_pmap`
`+ mem_range_iff`
`+ mem_singleton`
`+ mem_singleton_iff`
`+ not_mem_empty`
`+ ofFun_ne_empty`
`+ ofFun_ne_singleton`
`+ pmap`
`+ pmap_empty`
`+ pmap_eq_empty_iff`
`+ pmap_ofFun`
`+ pmap_singleton`
`+ range`
`+ range_empty`
`+ range_ofFun`
`+ range_singleton`
`+ singleton_def`
`+ singleton_ne_empty`
`+ singleton_ne_ofFun`
`+ toList`
`+ toList_empty`
`+ toList_ofFun`
`+ toList_singleton`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Yep, `Γ₀` is my goal for Mathlib. Though in my own repository, I'm trying to get to the much larger (although much less known) [extended Buchholz ordinal](https://googology.miraheze.org/wiki/Extended_Buchholz%27s_function).
I've changed the link to my repository to a more precise link to the section where I use this API.

This is very cool! I think your notations repository shows that the basic design of this Sequence API works, and I don't see any quirks to point out (more experienced mathlibers probably will).

I'm learning about this as I go, one of the goals of this is to have completely recursive fundamental sequences for ordinals up to Gamma0, right? Or maybe this is a special case of more general constructions.

This is very cool! I think your notations repository shows that the basic design of this Sequence API works, and I don't see any quirks to point out (more experienced mathlibers probably will).

I'm learning about this as I go, one of the goals of this is to have completely recursive fundamental sequences for ordinals up to Gamma0, right? Or maybe this is a special case of more general constructions.
I'm not seeing much about Sequence in the file you linked - can you say more about exactly where and how you use this definition?
Maybe useful to add here that every element of the sequence is meant to be below `x` (otherwise I'll just take the constant sequence `x` as a fundamental sequence)

That's implied by the phrasing "strictly monotonic".

Some authors leave fundamental sequences undefined for non-successor limits, so I'm starting the docstring with that phrase as a sort of common ground.
In that case you should give some justification for your definition on non-successor limits

Every ordinal `o` can be said to have a fundamental sequence, if by that we mean a strictly monotonic function `Ioo (cof o) → Ioo o` with cofinal range. In fact, this is already the definition of [`Ordinal.IsFundamentalSequence`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Cofinality.html#Ordinal.IsFundamentalSequence). This in particular implies the unique fundamental sequence for `0` is the empty function, and the unique fundamental sequence for `succ o` is `fun _ ↦ o`.

I'll add something like this as justification to the docstring.
Yup, that's sufficient justification!
and my comment above justifies why this needs to be `{x}` and not `{succ x}` (which confused me initially)

I wonder if it's more helpful to define this as an inductive type with three constructors, then you can give semantic names to the three options. Rather than `inl none`, `inl (some x)`, `inr f`, you'd have `Empty`, `Singleton`, `OfFun` or something...

Would that give us the `{x} = Ø` and such lemmas for free? If so, then it definitely seems cleaner. If not, then really the fact that this is defined as a sum type is nothing but an implementation detail anyways.

It wouldn't give those for free (I believe, since there's still the notation in the way), but it would mean that `ofFun` would be already given rather than a separate definition together with a simp lemma (ie `sum_inr_def` wouldn't need to exist). It'd also mean that recursion would have more meaningful names, such as in the def of `range`.
Just did this change, and I do find things to be simpler. Thanks!
This one doesn't have any API for now - let's either give api here or leave it for a future PR which can add that instead (eg that `(toList s n).length <= n`)

My intended usage is to call something like `#eval s.toList 10` in order to see the first few terms of the fundamental sequence. So having no API is actually fine.

Note that the lemma you write is false for `n = 0`, as I'm hardcoding `toList {x} = [x]`. Of course, we could do something like `toList {x} = if n = 0 then [] else [x]`, but given that I don't plan on using this definition mathematically, I wouldn't bother with this.

> My intended usage is to call something like `#eval s.toList 10` in order to see the first few terms of the fundamental sequence. So having no API is actually fine.

Unfortunately this isn't sufficient justification for not having API for a definition - even if the intended usage is in a particular way, there still should be lemmas describing it. Mathlib isn't just used by you!
I'll add the projection lemmas. If someone needs this definition for something else, then we can figure out if `toList {x}` should be redefined, what other API we should have, and so on.

```suggestion
/-- Recursion on sequences, using the preferred forms of the constructors. -/
@[elab_as_elim, induction_eliminator]
def recOn {p : Sequence α → Sort*} (s : Sequence α) (empty : p ∅) (singleton : ∀ x, p {x})
```
I think. @eric-wieser can you confirm this is what's useful?
This makes sense I think, though I'm not sure what this attribute actually does.

pullRequest.title: feat(SetTheory/Ordinal/Notation/FundamentalSequence): define type of fundamental sequences
